trans-unit.source: Use Linux compute VMs in an HPC Pack cluster | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Use Linux compute VMs in an HPC Pack cluster | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to script the deployment of an HPC Pack cluster in Azure containing a head node running Windows Server with Linux compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to script the deployment of an HPC Pack cluster in Azure containing a head node running Windows Server with Linux compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: Get started with Linux compute nodes in an HPC Pack cluster in Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Linux compute nodes in an HPC Pack cluster in Azure

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to use an Azure PowerShell script to set up a Microsoft HPC Pack cluster in Azure which contains a head node running Windows Server and several compute nodes running a CentOS Linux distribution.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to use an Azure PowerShell script to set up a Microsoft HPC Pack cluster in Azure which contains a head node running Windows Server and several compute nodes running a CentOS Linux distribution.

trans-unit.source: We also show several ways to move data files to the Linux compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: We also show several ways to move data files to the Linux compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: You can use this cluster to run Linux HPC workloads in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can use this cluster to run Linux HPC workloads in Azure.

trans-unit.source: At a high level the following diagram shows the HPC Pack cluster you'll create.
trans-unit.target: At a high level the following diagram shows the HPC Pack cluster you'll create.

trans-unit.target: ![HPC cluster with Linux nodes][scenario]

trans-unit.source: Deploy an HPC Pack cluster with Linux compute nodes
trans-unit.target: Deploy an HPC Pack cluster with Linux compute nodes

trans-unit.source: You'll use the Microsoft HPC Pack IaaS deployment script (**New-HpcIaaSCluster.ps1**) to automate the cluster deployment in Azure infrastructure services (IaaS).
trans-unit.target: You'll use the Microsoft HPC Pack IaaS deployment script (**New-HpcIaaSCluster.ps1**) to automate the cluster deployment in Azure infrastructure services (IaaS).

trans-unit.source: This Azure PowerShell script uses an HPC Pack VM image in the Azure Marketplace for fast deployment and provides a comprehensive set of configuration parameters to make the deployment easy and flexible.
trans-unit.target: This Azure PowerShell script uses an HPC Pack VM image in the Azure Marketplace for fast deployment and provides a comprehensive set of configuration parameters to make the deployment easy and flexible.

trans-unit.source: The script deploys the Azure virtual network, storage accounts, cloud services, domain controller, optional separate SQL Server database server, cluster head node, compute nodes, broker nodes, Azure PaaS (“burst”) nodes, and Linux compute nodes (Linux support introduced in [HPC Pack 2012 R2 Update 2](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/mt269417.aspx)).
trans-unit.target: The script deploys the Azure virtual network, storage accounts, cloud services, domain controller, optional separate SQL Server database server, cluster head node, compute nodes, broker nodes, Azure PaaS (“burst”) nodes, and Linux compute nodes (Linux support introduced in [HPC Pack 2012 R2 Update 2](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/mt269417.aspx)).

trans-unit.source: For an overview of HPC Pack cluster deployment options, see the [Getting Started Guide for HPC Pack 2012 R2 and HPC Pack 2012](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj884144.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For an overview of HPC Pack cluster deployment options, see the [Getting Started Guide for HPC Pack 2012 R2 and HPC Pack 2012](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj884144.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: **Client computer** - You'll need a Windows-based client computer to run the cluster deployment script.
trans-unit.target: **Client computer** - You'll need a Windows-based client computer to run the cluster deployment script.

trans-unit.target: **HPC Pack IaaS deployment script** - Download and unpack the latest version of the script from the [Microsoft Download Center](https://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=44949).

trans-unit.source: Create the configuration file
trans-unit.target: Create the configuration file

trans-unit.source: The HPC Pack IaaS deployment script uses an XML configuration file as input which describes the infrastructure of the HPC cluster.
trans-unit.target: The HPC Pack IaaS deployment script uses an XML configuration file as input which describes the infrastructure of the HPC cluster.

trans-unit.source: To deploy a small cluster consisting of a head node and 2 Linux compute nodes, substitute values for your environment into the following sample configuration file.
trans-unit.target: To deploy a small cluster consisting of a head node and 2 Linux compute nodes, substitute values for your environment into the following sample configuration file.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the configuration file, see the Manual.rtf file in the script folder or the [script documentation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn864734.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about the configuration file, see the Manual.rtf file in the script folder or the [script documentation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn864734.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Here are brief descriptions of the elements in the configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Here are brief descriptions of the elements in the configuration file.

trans-unit.source: **IaaSClusterConfig** - Root element of the configuration file.
trans-unit.target: **IaaSClusterConfig** - Root element of the configuration file.

trans-unit.source: **Subscription** - Azure subscription used to deploy the HPC Pack cluster.
trans-unit.target: **Subscription** - Azure subscription used to deploy the HPC Pack cluster.

trans-unit.source: Use the command below to make sure the Azure subscription name is configured and unique in your client computer.
trans-unit.target: Use the command below to make sure the Azure subscription name is configured and unique in your client computer.

trans-unit.source: In this sample, we use the Azure subscription “Subscription-1”.
trans-unit.target: In this sample, we use the Azure subscription “Subscription-1”.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]Alternatively, you can use the subscription ID to specify the subscription you want to use.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]Alternatively, you can use the subscription ID to specify the subscription you want to use.

trans-unit.source: See the Manual.rtf file in the script folder.
trans-unit.target: See the Manual.rtf file in the script folder.

trans-unit.source: **StorageAccount** - All the persistent data for the HPC Pack cluster will be stored to the specified storage account (allvhdsje in this example).
trans-unit.target: **StorageAccount** - All the persistent data for the HPC Pack cluster will be stored to the specified storage account (allvhdsje in this example).

trans-unit.source: If the storage account doesn’t exist, the script will create it in the region specified in **Location**.
trans-unit.target: If the storage account doesn’t exist, the script will create it in the region specified in **Location**.

trans-unit.source: **Location** - Azure region where you'll deploy the HPC Pack cluster (Japan East in this example).
trans-unit.target: **Location** - Azure region where you'll deploy the HPC Pack cluster (Japan East in this example).

trans-unit.source: **VNet** - Settings of the virtual network and subnet where the HPC cluster will be created.
trans-unit.target: **VNet** - Settings of the virtual network and subnet where the HPC cluster will be created.

trans-unit.source: You can create the virtual network and subnet yourself before running this script, or the script creates a virtual network with address space 192.168.0.0/20, and subnet with address space 192.168.0.0/23.
trans-unit.target: You can create the virtual network and subnet yourself before running this script, or the script creates a virtual network with address space 192.168.0.0/20, and subnet with address space 192.168.0.0/23.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the script creates the virtual network centos7rdmavnetje and subnet CentOS7RDMACluster.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the script creates the virtual network centos7rdmavnetje and subnet CentOS7RDMACluster.

trans-unit.source: **Domain** - Active Directory domain settings for the HPC Pack cluster.
trans-unit.target: **Domain** - Active Directory domain settings for the HPC Pack cluster.

trans-unit.source: All the Windows VMs created by the script will join the domain.
trans-unit.target: All the Windows VMs created by the script will join the domain.

trans-unit.source: Currently, the script supports three domain options: ExistingDC, NewDC, and HeadNodeAsDC.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the script supports three domain options: ExistingDC, NewDC, and HeadNodeAsDC.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we will configure the head node as the domain controller with a fully qualified domain name of hpc.local.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we will configure the head node as the domain controller with a fully qualified domain name of hpc.local.

trans-unit.source: **Database** - Database settings for the HPC Pack cluster.
trans-unit.target: **Database** - Database settings for the HPC Pack cluster.

trans-unit.source: Currently, the script supports three database options: ExistingDB, NewRemoteDB, and LocalDB.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the script supports three database options: ExistingDB, NewRemoteDB, and LocalDB.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we will create a local database on the head node.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we will create a local database on the head node.

trans-unit.source: **HeadNode** - Settings for the HPC Pack head node.
trans-unit.target: **HeadNode** - Settings for the HPC Pack head node.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we will create a size A7 head node named CentOS7RDMA-HN in the cloud service centos7rdma-je.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we will create a size A7 head node named CentOS7RDMA-HN in the cloud service centos7rdma-je.

trans-unit.source: To support HPC job submission from remote (non-domain-joined) client computers, the script will enable the HPC job scheduler REST API and HPC web portal.
trans-unit.target: To support HPC job submission from remote (non-domain-joined) client computers, the script will enable the HPC job scheduler REST API and HPC web portal.

trans-unit.source: **LinuxComputeNodes** - Settings for the HPC Pack Linux compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: **LinuxComputeNodes** - Settings for the HPC Pack Linux compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: In this xample, we will create two size A7 CentOS 7 Linux compute nodes (CentOS7RDMA-LN1 and CentOS7RDMA-LN2) in the cloud service centos7rdma-je.
trans-unit.target: In this xample, we will create two size A7 CentOS 7 Linux compute nodes (CentOS7RDMA-LN1 and CentOS7RDMA-LN2) in the cloud service centos7rdma-je.

trans-unit.source: How to move data in a cluster with Linux nodes
trans-unit.target: How to move data in a cluster with Linux nodes

trans-unit.source: You have several choices to move data among Linux nodes and the Windows head node of the cluster.
trans-unit.target: You have several choices to move data among Linux nodes and the Windows head node of the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Here are three common methods.
trans-unit.target: Here are three common methods.

trans-unit.source: **Azure File** - Exposes a file share to store data files in Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: **Azure File** - Exposes a file share to store data files in Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: Both Windows nodes and the Linux nodes can mount an Azure File share as a drive or folder at the same time even if they are deployed in different virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: Both Windows nodes and the Linux nodes can mount an Azure File share as a drive or folder at the same time even if they are deployed in different virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: **Head node SMB share** - Mounts a shared folder of the head node on Linux nodes.
trans-unit.target: **Head node SMB share** - Mounts a shared folder of the head node on Linux nodes.

trans-unit.source: **Head node NFS server** - Provides a file-sharing solution for a mixed Windows and Linux environment.
trans-unit.target: **Head node NFS server** - Provides a file-sharing solution for a mixed Windows and Linux environment.

trans-unit.source: Azure File
trans-unit.target: Azure File

trans-unit.source: The [Azure File](https://azure.microsoft.com/services/storage/files/) service exposes file shares using the standard SMB 2.1 protocol.
trans-unit.target: The [Azure File](https://azure.microsoft.com/services/storage/files/) service exposes file shares using the standard SMB 2.1 protocol.

trans-unit.source: Azure VMs and cloud services can share file data across application components via mounted shares, and on-premises applications can access file data in a share through the File storage API.
trans-unit.target: Azure VMs and cloud services can share file data across application components via mounted shares, and on-premises applications can access file data in a share through the File storage API.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to use Azure File storage with PowerShell and .NET](../storage/storage-dotnet-how-to-use-files.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to use Azure File storage with PowerShell and .NET](../storage/storage-dotnet-how-to-use-files.md).

trans-unit.source: To create an Azure File share, see the detailed steps in [Introducing Microsoft Azure File Service](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2014/05/12/introducing-microsoft-azure-file-service.aspx).
trans-unit.target: To create an Azure File share, see the detailed steps in [Introducing Microsoft Azure File Service](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2014/05/12/introducing-microsoft-azure-file-service.aspx).

trans-unit.source: To set up persisting connections, see [Persisting connections to Microsoft Azure Files](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2014/05/27/persisting-connections-to-microsoft-azure-files.aspx).
trans-unit.target: To set up persisting connections, see [Persisting connections to Microsoft Azure Files](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/windowsazurestorage/archive/2014/05/27/persisting-connections-to-microsoft-azure-files.aspx).

trans-unit.target: In this example, we create an Azure File share named rdma on our storage account allvhdsje.

trans-unit.source: Head node share
trans-unit.target: Head node share

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can mount a shared folder of the head node on Linux nodes.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can mount a shared folder of the head node on Linux nodes.

trans-unit.source: This is the simplest way to share files, but the head node and all Linux nodes have to be deployed in the same virtual network.
trans-unit.target: This is the simplest way to share files, but the head node and all Linux nodes have to be deployed in the same virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Here are the steps.
trans-unit.target: Here are the steps.

trans-unit.target: Create a folder on the head node and share it to Everyone with Read/Write permissions.

trans-unit.source: NFS server
trans-unit.target: NFS server

trans-unit.source: The NFS service enables users to share and migrate files between computers running the Windows Server 2012 operating system using the SMB protocol and Linux-based computers using the NFS protocol.
trans-unit.target: The NFS service enables users to share and migrate files between computers running the Windows Server 2012 operating system using the SMB protocol and Linux-based computers using the NFS protocol.

trans-unit.source: The NFS server and all other nodes have to be deployed in same virtual network.
trans-unit.target: The NFS server and all other nodes have to be deployed in same virtual network.

trans-unit.source: It provides better compatibility with Linux nodes compared with an SMB share; for example, it supports file link.
trans-unit.target: It provides better compatibility with Linux nodes compared with an SMB share; for example, it supports file link.

trans-unit.source: To install and set up an NFS server, follow the steps in [Server for Network File System First Share End-to-End](http://blogs.technet.com/b/filecab/archive/2012/10/08/server-for-network-file-system-first-share-end-to-end.aspx).
trans-unit.target: To install and set up an NFS server, follow the steps in [Server for Network File System First Share End-to-End](http://blogs.technet.com/b/filecab/archive/2012/10/08/server-for-network-file-system-first-share-end-to-end.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Open a Windows PowerShell window and run the following command to mount the NFS share.
trans-unit.target: Open a Windows PowerShell window and run the following command to mount the NFS share.

trans-unit.source: The first command creates a folder named /nfsshared on all nodes in the LinuxNodes group.
trans-unit.target: The first command creates a folder named /nfsshared on all nodes in the LinuxNodes group.

trans-unit.source: The second command mounts the NFS share CentOS7RDMA-HN:/nfs onto the folder.
